sn22.57:1.2: “Mendicants, in this teaching and training a mendicant who is skilled in seven cases and who examines in three ways is called consummate, accomplished, a supreme person.
sn22.57:1.3: And how is a mendicant skilled in seven cases?
sn22.57:1.4: It’s when a mendicant understands form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
sn22.57:1.5: They understand form’s gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn22.57:1.9: consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
sn22.57:1.10: They understand consciousness’s gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn22.57:2.2: The four primary elements, and form derived from the four primary elements.
sn22.57:2.6: The practice that leads to the cessation of form is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn22.57:2.7: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
sn22.57:3.1: The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.
sn22.57:3.3: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
sn22.57:3.5: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.
sn22.57:4.1: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known form in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;
sn22.57:4.2: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and are practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form: they are practicing well.
sn22.57:4.3: Those who practice well have a firm footing in this teaching and training.
sn22.57:5.1: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known form in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;
sn22.57:5.2: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, are freed by not grasping: they are well freed.
sn22.57:5.3: Those who are well freed are consummate ones.
sn22.57:5.4: For consummate ones, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.
sn22.57:6.2: There are these six classes of feeling:
sn22.57:6.8: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn22.57:6.9: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
sn22.57:7.1: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling: this is its gratification.
sn22.57:7.3: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
sn22.57:7.5: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape. …
sn22.57:10.2: There are these six classes of perception:
sn22.57:10.3: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
sn22.57:10.7: The practice that leads to the cessation of perceptions is simply this noble eightfold path …
sn22.57:11.2: There are these six classes of intention:
sn22.57:11.8: The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this noble eightfold path …
sn22.57:14.2: There are these six classes of consciousness:
sn22.57:14.3: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.
sn22.57:14.5: Consciousness originates from name and form.
sn22.57:14.6: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.
sn22.57:14.7: The practice that leads to the cessation of consciousness is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn22.57:14.8: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
sn22.57:15.1: The pleasure and happiness that arise from consciousness: this is its gratification.
sn22.57:15.3: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
sn22.57:15.5: Removing and giving up desire and greed for consciousness: this is its escape.
sn22.57:16.1: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known consciousness in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;
sn22.57:16.2: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and are practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness: they are practicing well.
sn22.57:16.3: Those who practice well have a firm footing in this teaching and training.
sn22.57:17.1: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known consciousness in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;
sn22.57:17.2: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, are freed by not grasping: they are well freed.
sn22.57:17.3: Those who are well freed are consummate ones.
sn22.57:17.4: For consummate ones, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.
sn22.57:17.5: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in seven cases.
sn22.57:18.1: And how does a mendicant examine in three ways?
sn22.57:18.2: It’s when a mendicant examines the elements, sense fields, and dependent origination.
sn22.57:18.3: That’s how a mendicant examines in three ways.
sn22.57:18.4: In this teaching and training, a mendicant who is skilled in seven cases and who examines in three ways is called consummate, accomplished, a supreme person.”
